message_1: Simplify the trigonometric expression: cos²(x) - sin²(x) if cos(x) = 2/3 and x is in the second quadrant.
message_2:
Since x is in the second quadrant, sin(x) will be positive. We can use the Pythagorean identity sin²(x) + cos²(x) = 1 to find sin(x).

cos²(x) = (2/3)² = 4/9

Now, we can find sin²(x):

sin²(x) + cos²(x) = 1
sin²(x) + 4/9 = 1
sin²(x) = 1 - 4/9
sin²(x) = 5/9

Since sin(x) is positive in the second quadrant, we can take the square root of sin²(x) to find sin(x):

sin(x) = √(5/9)
sin(x) = √5 / 3

Now we can substitute the values of sin(x) and cos(x) into the given expression:

cos²(x) - sin²(x) = (2/3)² - (√5 / 3)²
= 4/9 - 5/9
= -1/9

So, the simplified trigonometric expression is -1/9.
